text: hi I'm Melissa Clark from the dining
section do you smell what I smell oh no
I guess you don't
I've got cinnamon rolls in the oven
cinnamon rolls seemed like this big
intimidating project but the great thing
about them is you can make the dough the
night before then pop it in the oven
before your guests come for brunch first
thing is to make the dough which I'm
going to season with a little bit of
cardamom just to make it extra fragrant
I've warmed up some milk and melted
butter on the stove and I'm gonna pour
it into the mixer what's so great about
this recipe is that you don't need to
proof the yeast I'm just gonna throw it
right into the flour and then I'm gonna
add the rest of my ingredients cardamom
salt and dark brown sugar I'm gonna
throw my flour mixture in with my milk
and butter as soon as the flour gets
dampened I'm gonna crack in this egg for
the exact recipe go to nytimes.com slash
this is a little bit sticky so I'm gonna
add just a touch more flour you don't
want it to stick to your fingers once
the dough is come together you're gonna
put it on a floured counter and knead it
until its elastic if you've never needed
dough before it's really easy you just
want to press on it with the heels of
your hands now you see how it's started
to spring back when I press it that's
all there is to it so I've oiled up this
bowl same bowl that I used for the flour
by the way and I'm just gonna put the
dough in here I'm gonna cover it with
plastic wrap and let it rise until it's
doubled in bulk should take about two
hours while your dough is rising you can
make the filling I've got some dark
brown sugar a lot of cinnamon some
freshly grated nutmeg and a little salt
just mix them all together and I've also
browned some butter on the stove once
your dough has doubled in bulk see how
it's nice and puffy you just roll it out
to a rectangle that's about 11 by 15 now
you just want to brush the brown butter
all over the dough and then top it with
the cinnamon mixture and I am gonna
leave a half an inch border all around
that way I know that it's not gonna seep
all over the place you want to make sure
to cover up any bald spots
get a nice even layer I'm gonna roll
this up very tightly and then bring it
seam side down onto a cutting board now
I'm going to cut it into 18 pieces lay
the slices into two greased 9 by 9 inch
pans after you slice the cinnamon buns
you have two choices if you want to eat
them the same day you just let them rise
in a warm spot for 45 minutes until they
get puffy or if you want to serve them
tomorrow
just take the whole pan and let them
rise overnight in the fridge then in the
morning while the oven preheats take
them out let them get to room
temperature and then we're gonna bake
them in either case at 375 for 20
minutes while those rolls are in the
oven I'm gonna make a quick glaze so I'm
gonna make a brown sugar syrup with
water brown sugar of course suburban
vanilla and butter and then when that's
nice and thick I'm going to add
confectioner sugar last step pour the
glaze over the tops now you have to let
these rest for 20 minutes so that the
glaze can set and it's going to be the
longest 20 minutes of your life
